channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2022 The New York Times Company

item.title: What Happened on Day 22 of Russia’s Invasion of Ukraine
item.description: The suffering in Ukraine’s cities shows no sign of ending, even as Western officials say Russia’s offensive has stalled.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Ivor Prickett for The New York Times
item.media:description: Civilians arrived at an aid station in Kyiv, Ukraine’s capital, after being evacuated from the besieged town of Irpin.

item.title: Who Killed Three Aid Workers for Doctors Without Borders in Ethiopia?
item.description: Three employees of Doctors Without Borders set out to rescue the wounded in a war zone in northern Ethiopia. Their fate shows the treacherous path for many aid workers in conflict zones.
item.dc:creator: Simon Marks and Declan Walsh
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity

item.title: In Some Parts of the World, the War in Ukraine Seems Justified
item.description: In countries friendly toward Russia, people are troubled by the war and loss of life, but some say they think that Putin has a point.
item.dc:creator: John Eligon
item.media:description: A woman reads a Vietnamese newspaper featuring front-page coverage of the Russian invasion of Ukraine at her stall in Hanoi last month.

item.title: Peru’s Top Court Reinstates Pardon for Former President Alberto Fujimori
item.description: The court issued a ruling to release Mr. Fujimori from prison, where he has served less than 15 years of a 25-year sentence for committing human rights abuses. The government said it would appeal the ruling.
item.dc:creator: Mitra Taj
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Marco Garro for The New York Times
item.media:description: Peruvians in downtown Lima on Thursday protested a court ruling that reinstated a pardon for Alberto Fujimori, the country’s former authoritarian president, allowing him to leave prison.

item.title: War Strands Ukrainian and Russian Tourists Together in Egyptian Resorts
item.description: The tension in hotels and on Red Sea beaches is palpable, though there are also moments of compassion.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Yee
item.media:credit: Laura Boushnak for The New York Times
item.media:description: Tourists swam in Sharm el Sheikh, Egypt, this month. Some Ukrainian tourists said that they had tried, and largely failed, to persuade Russians that their country had done nothing to deserve invasion.

item.title: In South Korea, a Spike in Covid Cases Meets a Collective Shrug
item.description: A country that once had one of the world’s most aggressive coronavirus policies is opting to learn to live with the virus, even in the face of a soaring infection rate.
item.dc:creator: Victoria Kim and John Yoon
item.media:description: A crowded street in Seoul, South Korea, on Thursday, when the country set a daily record for coronavirus infections: 621,328.

item.title: Cambodia Convicts 19 Opposition Politicians on ‘Incitement’ Charges
item.description: Critics called the trial a “witch hunt,” and the latest effort by Prime Minister Hun Sen to eliminate the last vestiges of dissenting political voices in what was already a virtually one-party state.
item.dc:creator: Seth Mydans
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Tang Chhin Sothy/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: A prison van transporting jailed opposition members outside the Phnom Penh Municipal Court in Cambodia on Thursday.

item.title: As Russia Digs In, What’s the Risk of Nuclear War? ‘It’s Not Zero.’
item.description: A series of shifts in Russian statements about using nuclear weapons has led some analysts to believe that the Kremlin sees a nuclear exchange as a viable strategy.
item.dc:creator: Max Fisher
item.media:description: A Russian army RS-24 Yars ballistic missile system moving through Red Square during a military parade, in Moscow, in 2020.

item.title: Is This the World’s Largest Potato?
item.description: A couple in New Zealand found a giant growth in their garden, named it Doug and applied to Guinness World Records. Then the results of a DNA analysis came in.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: Doug, as bronze and burly as any Thanksgiving turkey, in Donna and Colin Craig-Browns’s garden near Hamilton, New Zealand, in November.

item.title: Oxxxymiron, Russian Rapper, Brings a Banned Antiwar Message to Istanbul
item.description: The rapper, Oxxxymiron, said proceeds from his show would go to help Ukrainian refugees. Russians at the concert denounced the war but said they felt helpless to stop it.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Nechepurenko
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: “I hate feeling so powerless,” Oxxxymiron, one of Russia’s most popular rappers, said at a benefit concert for Ukrainian refugees at an Istanbul club on Tuesday.

item.title: Italian Court Reduces Sentences for 2 Americans Convicted of Killing Police Officer
item.description: An appeals court confirmed the homicide verdicts but commuted the life terms for both men, handing Finnegan Elder 24 years in prison and Gabriel Natale Hjorth 22.
item.dc:creator: Elisabetta Povoledo
item.media:description: Gabriel Natale Hjorth, left, and Finnegan Elder during a court appearance in Rome last year. They were found guilty of killing a police officer while on vacation in 2019.

item.title: Mass Graves in Syria Could Hold Evidence of War Crimes
item.description: Two sites have been located, believed to hold thousands of bodies of Syrians killed in detention centers administered by President Bashar al-Assad’s government during the civil war.
item.dc:creator: Ben Hubbard and Marlise Simons
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity

item.title: Powerful Quake Off Japan Rekindles Fears of Another Fukushima
item.description: Tsunami warnings in a region hit by nuclear disaster in 2011 were lifted after a few hours. The damage was still being assessed, but it appeared contained.
item.dc:creator: Motoko Rich and Eric Nagourney
item.media:description: The Fukushima Daiichi nuclear power plant, which was seriously damaged by an earthquake and tsunami in 2011, earlier this month. Nuclear power plants were under inspection early Thursday.

item.title: War in Ukraine Prompts a Political Makeover in Poland
item.description: Jaroslaw Kaczynski, Poland’s de facto leader and longtime scourge of E.U. unity, is portraying himself as a standard-bearer of European solidarity in defense of Ukraine and democratic values.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Higgins
item.media:description: Jaroslaw Kaczynski, the leader of Poland’s governing party, during a meeting with President Volodymyr Zelensky in Kyiv this week.

item.title: A ‘Killing Stone’ Broke in Japan. Is a Demon on the Loose?
item.description: The rock appears in a famous legend starring a nine-tailed fox spirit. The question now is whether the fracture was a good or bad omen.
item.dc:creator: Mike Ives and Makiko Inoue
item.media:credit: Aflo Co. Ltd. / Alamy Stock Photo
item.media:description: The split rock, which resides at a national park north of Tokyo, is known as Sessho-seki, or “killing stone.”

item.title: Covid and the ‘Very Liberal’
item.description: There’s a schism among Democrats. And the latest on Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:credit: Andres Kudacki for The New York Times
item.media:description: Returning to school after the mask mandate was lifted in New York City.

item.title: Pope Deplores the War in Ukraine but Not the Aggressor
item.description: Francis has raised his voice against “unacceptable armed aggression” without mentioning President Vladimir V. Putin or Russia. Some analysts say that he risks complicating his legacy.
item.dc:creator: Jason Horowitz
item.media:description: Francis in Vatican City in February. The pope has worked hard to forge a rapprochement between Roman Catholicism and Eastern Orthodoxy.

item.title: For a Ukrainian Poet, Putin’s War Is All Too Familiar
item.description: Ihor Kalynets, 83, spent a lifetime resisting Soviet domination. Now, he says, he’s not going anywhere.
item.dc:creator: Carlotta Gall
item.media:credit: Ivor Prickett for The New York Times

item.title: Internation Energy Agency Says Nations Should Conserve Fuel as Global Energy Crisis Looms
item.description: The International Energy Agency said countries should encourage use of mass transit and car pooling, among other things. That could also help the climate crisis.
item.dc:creator: Catrin Einhorn and Lisa Friedman
item.media:credit: Patrick T. Fallon/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: The International Energy Agency’s report details 10 immediate steps that nations should take to conserve oil and gas, including car-free Sundays in cities, car pooling and use of trains instead of planes when possible.

item.title: How the War in Ukraine Could Slow the Sales of Electric Cars
item.description: The price of nickel, an essential ingredient in most batteries, has soared because of fear that Russian supplies could be cut off.
item.dc:creator: Jack Ewing and Stephen Gandel
item.media:credit: Maxim Babenko for The New York Times
item.media:description: The city of Norilsk, Russia, is a nickel-mining hub.

item.title: Your Friday Briefing
item.description: Casualties in the war in Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: Grieving in Kyiv yesterday.

item.title: Kids, Covid Isolation and Learning to Endure
item.description: The virus found us, and we’re doing just fine. I think.
item.dc:creator: Damien Cave
item.media:description: The Howard Springs Covid quarantine center is the only one of its kind in Australia.

item.title: U.S. Says Russia Committed War Crimes, but Consequences Are Unclear
item.description: A day after President Biden’s remark, Secretary of State Antony Blinken said he agreed. Experts warned of hurdles to a successful prosecution.
item.dc:creator: Michael Crowley
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: Residents trying to salvage whatever they can after the shelling of a residential building in Kyiv, Ukraine, on Monday.

item.title: By Labeling Putin a ‘War Criminal,’ Biden Personalizes the Conflict
item.description: President Biden’s visceral reaction to the horrifying images coming out of Ukraine also reflects a broader effort to isolate the Russian leader.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:credit: Kenny Holston for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Biden called President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia a “war criminal” on Wednesday.

item.title: Why Vladimir Putin Invokes Nazis to Justify His Invasion of Ukraine
item.description: The language of Russia’s invasion has been dominated by the word “Nazi” — a puzzling assertion about a country whose leader is Jewish.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski
item.media:description: Billboards quoting President Vladimir V. Putin in Simferopol, Crimea, this month. The one on the right reads “We want the demilitarization and denazification of Ukraine.”

item.title: Survivors Emerge From a Bombed Theater, but Ukraine’s Suffering Grows
item.description: Russia continues to devastate cities and hit civilians, as Ukrainian forces strike back and peace talks drag on.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer, Michael Schwirtz and Eric Nagourney

item.title: Your Friday Briefing: The Destruction of Ukraine
item.description: Plus South Korea’s new approach to the virus and Cambodia’s crackdown on opposition leaders.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: Tetiana Vaskovska, 58, wept as she collected family photographs from the remnants of her home in Kyiv.

item.title: House Votes to Suspend Normal Trade Relations With Russia
item.description: The bill, which still needs Senate approval, is the latest in a series of measures that lawmakers have passed to support Ukraine and punish Russia for its invasion.
item.dc:creator: Catie Edmondson
item.media:description: A customs officer walked past shipping containers in Kaliningrad, Russia, last year. The bill passed by the House would allow the United States to impose higher tariffs on Russian goods.

item.title: NOAA Expects Drought Conditions to Persist Through the Spring
item.description: Winter precipitation amounts were not enough to significantly improve conditions in much of the country, government scientists said.
item.dc:creator: Maggie Astor
item.media:description: Lake Oroville in California last summer.

item.title: Emmanuel Macron Argues for Second Term as French President
item.description: The Ukraine war has given the French leader a strong edge and few reasons to engage with his political opponents. He held a news conference to quell criticism that he is avoiding debate.
item.dc:creator: Norimitsu Onishi and Aurelien Breeden
item.media:description: Mr. Macron speaking on Thursday in Aubervilliers, north of Paris. The news conference served as a rebuttal to rising criticism that he has not engaged in any debate or laid out an agenda.

item.title: LGBTQ Activists in Ukraine Share the Fight Against Russia’s Invasion
item.description: A pro-Russian puppet government would be less supportive of gay rights, the activists say, and incidents of discrimination would be likely to rise, as they have in Russian-backed separatist regions.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Mpoke Bigg
item.media:description: The Pride Parade in Kyiv, Ukraine, last September.

item.title: Countries Previously Hostile to Refugees Embrace Ukrainians
item.description: While the warm welcome has been applauded, some human rights advocates point to a humanitarian double standard when it comes to refugees from the Middle East and Africa.
item.dc:creator: Niki Kitsantonis, Christina Anderson and Emma Bubola
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainian refugees in Hungary ate some food provided to them after arriving at the train station in Zahony, a small town near the two countries’ border.

item.title: Arnold Schwarzenegger Tapes Video to Russia, Telling Putin: ‘Stop This War’
item.description: The movie star and former governor of California addressed Russians and Russian soldiers, saying, “ “your lives, your limbs, your futures are being sacrificed for a senseless war.”
item.dc:creator: Shawn Hubler
item.media:credit: Tracy Nguyen for The New York Times
item.media:description: In a video released on Thursday, Arnold Schwarzenegger addressed Russian soldiers, civilians, and President Vladimir Putin.

item.title: In a First, Catholic Cardinal Testifies in Vatican Criminal Trial
item.description: Accused of embezzlement and abuse of office, Cardinal Giovanni Angelo Becciu told the court that he was sure the truth would clear his name.
item.dc:creator: Elisabetta Povoledo
item.media:description: Cardinal Giovanni Angelo Becciu in Rome in 2020. He faces a criminal trial over a London real-estate deal.

item.title: Russian Court Extends Brittney Griner’s Detention
item.description: Griner, one of the world’s best basketball players, was detained on accusations that she had hashish oil in her luggage at an airport outside of Moscow a week before Russia invaded Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Holpuch
item.media:description: Brittney Griner, a W.N.B.A. All-Star center for the Phoenix Mercury, has been detained on drug charges in Russia since Feb. 17

item.title: Biden Cancels In-Person Meetings with Micheal Martin, Who Tested Positive
item.description: The prime minister’s test result came amid a burst of infections among public officials in Washington in recent days.
item.dc:creator: Michael D. Shear, Ed O’Loughlin, Alyssa Lukpat, Emily Cochrane, Adeel Hassan and Alexandra E. Petri
item.media:description: President Biden participating in a virtual meeting with Prime Minister Micheal Martin of Ireland in the Oval Office on Thursday.

item.title: Russia appears to have avoided default as it makes a $117 million bond payment.
item.description: Sanctions have isolated the country financially, driven down the value of the ruble and cut off Moscow’s access to about half its foreign currency reserves.
item.dc:creator: Kevin Granville, Eshe Nelson and Lananh Nguyen
item.category: Credit Ratings and Credit Rating Agencies

item.title: Amid Invasion of Ukraine, I.R.S. Aims to Police Oligarch Sanctions
item.description: It wants to add agents to a 3,000-person investigations unit to help crack down on attempts by Russian oligarchs to evade sanctions.
item.dc:creator: Alan Rappeport
item.media:description: Charles Rettig, the tax agency commissioner, is asking Congress for more than $5 billion to expand its role in investigating attempts to evade U.S. sanctions on Russia.

item.title: For some transgender people, remote work meant a chance to take the next steps in their transitions.
item.dc:creator: Jenny Gross and Alyssa Lukpat
item.media:credit: Daniel Lozada for The New York Times
item.media:description: Deke Wilson at home in Parma, Ohio. Mr. Wilson used the time away from the office to undergo five gender transition surgeries.

item.title: A City Under Siege
item.description: We give you a rare dispatch from Mariupol, Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:description: Dead bodies are put into a mass grave on the outskirts of Mariupol, Ukraine.

item.title: UNESCO Will Send Body Armor to Ukrainian Journalists
item.description: The U.N. agency said thousands of Ukrainian journalists with no protective equipment or training were now covering the war. At least four journalists have been killed.
item.dc:creator: Jane Arraf
item.category: United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization
item.media:description: Pierre Zakrzewski, a Fox News cameraman, left, and Oleksandra Kuvshynova, a Ukrainian journalist, center right, were killed outside Kyiv on Monday.

item.title: Honduras Judge Approves Extradition of Ex-President to U.S.
item.description: Former President Juan Orlando Hernández is facing drug-trafficking and weapons charges
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press
item.media:description: Former President Juan Orlando Hernández in shackles at the headquarters of the national police in Tegucigalpa, Honduras, in February.

item.title: Your Thursday Briefing
item.description: More U.S. military aid for Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: A Ukranian soldier in the strategic port city of Odessa.

item.title: U.S. Adds ‘Kamikaze Drones’ as More Weapons Flow to Ukraine
item.description: NATO allies are focused on providing Kyiv with high-tech defensive weapons that are easy to use and move.
item.dc:creator: Julian E. Barnes and John Ismay
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainian fighters training in early March to use a British-provided NLAW antitank weapon.

item.title: Biden Calls Putin ‘War Criminal’ in Verbal Escalation With Russia
item.description: The U.S. president’s unscripted remarks echoed comments other American officials have made recently.
item.dc:creator: Azi Paybarah
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:credit: Kenny Holston for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Biden speaking in Washington on Wednesday.

item.title: Zelensky Pleads for More U.S. Aid, Invoking America’s Darkest Days
item.description: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine called for a no-fly zone and more weapons to combat Russia’s assault and implored President Biden to be “the leader of peace.”
item.dc:creator: Catie Edmondson and Michael D. Shear
item.media:description: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine delivered a virtual address to Congress on Wednesday.

item.title: As Russian Troop Deaths Climb, Morale May Be an Issue
item.description: More than 7,000 Russian troops have been killed in less than three weeks of fighting, according to conservative U.S. estimates.
item.dc:creator: Helene Cooper, Julian E. Barnes and Eric Schmitt
item.media:description: A Ukrainian soldier used an antitank weapon to destroy a Russian vehicle in Irpin, Ukraine, last week.

item.title: Spain Seizes Another Russian Yacht Believed to Belong to an Oligarch
item.description: The ship was impounded in the Spanish port of Tarragona pending an inspection to establish its exact ownership, Spain’s transport ministry said.
item.dc:creator: Raphael Minder and Michael Forsythe
item.media:description: A security guard stood at the dock where the Crescent, a megayacht, was docked in Tarragona, Spain. The Crescent was impounded by the Spanish government on Wednesday.

item.title: Transcript: Zelensky’s Speech to Congress
item.description: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine addressed a joint meeting of the House and Senate to press his case for more aid to Ukraine amid devastating attacks by Russia.
item.dc:creator: Catie Edmondson
item.media:description: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine delivered a virtual address to Congress on Wednesday.

item.title: Iran’s Attack Was Response to Secret Israeli Attack on Drone Site
item.description: Israel and Iran are pushing the boundaries of a long-running clandestine war that is increasingly spilling out of the shadows.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi, Ronen Bergman and Eric Schmitt
item.media:description: Iranian missiles struck this building in Erbil, Iraq, on Sunday that Iran said housed an Israeli intelligence operation.

item.title: W.H.O. Delays Assessing Russia’s Sputnik Vaccine Over Ukraine War
item.description: An official with the World Health Organization said “the assessment, along with inspections, have been affected.”
item.dc:creator: Adeel Hassan
item.category: Gamaleya Research Institute of Epidemiology and Microbiology
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: Nurses administering doses of Covid-19 vaccines in Moscow in July.

item.title: Your Thursday Briefing: Zelensky Speaks to Congress
item.description: Plus an offshore earthquake in Japan and mass graves in Syria.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:description: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine delivers a virtual address to Congress in the U.S. Capitol Visitors Center Congressional Auditorium in Washington, D.C.

item.title: Justin Smith, Former Bloomberg C.E.O., Offers New Details on Media Start-up
item.description: The former Bloomberg Media C.E.O. offered new details on the venture he is starting with the journalist Ben Smith.
item.dc:creator: Michael M. Grynbaum
item.media:description: Justin Smith in 2014. The new publication, its co-founder said, “is very intentionally going to be able to live in Asia or Europe or the Middle East or America.”

item.title: Putin Assails Russians Who Back the West, Signaling More Repression
item.description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia denigrated European and American leaders, and Russians who disagreed with him. Analysts fear his remarks could signal a new wave of repression.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski
item.media:description: An antiwar protester being carried away by Russian police officers during a demonstration in Moscow last month.

item.title: Saharan Sands Float North to Europe, Coating Cities With Dust
item.description: A European monitoring service projected that the dust, which cast an eerie orange pall over much of the continent, could reach as far as Denmark.
item.dc:creator: Daniel Victor and Raphael Minder
item.media:description: Vast stretches of Spain, including the Almeria fortress, were cloaked in orange as airborne dust particles wafted up from the Sahara.

item.title: Olga Smirnova, Opposed to the Ukraine War, Quits the Bolshoi
item.description: Olga Smirnova said she was against the war in Ukraine “with all the fibers of my soul.” Now, she has joined the Dutch National Ballet.
item.dc:creator: Alex Marshall
item.media:credit: Pool photo by Ekaterina Shtukina/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: Olga Smirnova, with Artemy Belyakov, in George Balanchine’s “Diamonds” at the Bolshoi in Moscow in 2019.

item.title: Exports to Russia Blocked by U.S. and Its Allies
item.description: To try to halt the war in Ukraine, the U.S. and its allies have imposed the most sweeping export controls seen in decades on Russia. Now they have to enforce them.
item.dc:creator: Ana Swanson
item.media:description: The Yangshan Deep Water Port in Shanghai. Chinese officials have hinted that they will comply with export controls put in place by the United States to keep advanced technology from Russia.
